The past decades have witnessed significant advances in nanoscience and technology, especially in the variety of colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors. Among these nanosensors, colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors based on in situ formed nanomaterials have attracted much attention due to their ease of operation and high sensitivity. This review focuses on the significant achievements of the past ten years in colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors by utilizing in situ produced nanomaterials, including gold nanoparticles, silver nanoparticles, CdS quantum dots, fluorescent silver nanoparticles, fluorescent copper nanoparticles, carbon quantum dots, fluorescent silicon nanoparticles and fluorescent cadmium nanoclusters. At the end of the review, the challenges and future directions are presented.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Over the past decades, various nanomaterials have attracted tremendous attention due to their unique properties and fascinating potential applications in various areas [1–3]. Development of nanosensors is one of the most important applications. In particular, optical nanosensors have been the focus of considerable interest due to their high sensitivity, good selectivity and simplicity. Of these, colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors are the most popular due to their convenience and easy-to-use nature [2–6]. For example, we have presented a label-free colorimetric method for sensing Cd2+ ions using gold nanoparticles (AuNPs). AuNPs were first prepared via the reduction of HAuCl4 by sodium citrate under reflux conditions. AuNPs easily aggregated in high-salt conditions, but the addition of glutathione (GSH) can prevent salt-induced aggregation of AuNPs. In the presence of Cd2+ ions, AuNPs still aggregate under high-salt conditions due to the coordination of the Cd2+ ions with GSH, as a result, the Cd2+ ion is selectively assayed based on the color change of AuNPs [7]. Liu’s group presented a one-step approach for the synthesis of porphyrin functionalized ceria (Por-Ceria) that was utilized for the colorimetric detection of H2O2 and glucose, because Por-Ceria displayed strong intrinsic peroxidase activity. In the detection system, Por-Ceria was firstly prepared and purified through centrifugation, and then detection of H2O2 was achieved after adding the peroxidase substrate 3,3’,5,5’-tetramethylbenzidine. When combined with glucose oxidase, glucose was successfully assayed [8]. Fluorescent carbon nanoparticles (F-CNPs), new type of fluorescent nanomaterial, have been widely applied for the fluorescent sensing of various analytes. B,N,S-co-doped F-CNPs (BNS-F-CNPs) with a red emission have been firstly prepared via the hydrothermal treatment of 2,5- diaminobenzenesulfonic acid and 4-aminophenylboronic acid hydrochloride. After centrifugation and dialysis, the purified BNSF-CNPs were successfully utilized for colorimetric and fluorescent sensing of Fe3+ ions with good sensitivity [9]. We have also synthesized B,N-co-doped F-CNPs (BN-F-CNPs) through a hydrothermal method. After purification of the BN-F-CNPs via dialysis, the purified BN-F-CNPs were then applied to sense Cr(VI) ions [10]. These conventional optical nanosensors exhibited excellent performance, but the preparation of the nanomaterials and detection of analytes are separate issues, which may require more time to operate and produce much waste. Therefore, the development of simpler and more convenient optical nanosensors is still highly desirable.
Recently, optical nanosensors based on the in situ mediated formation of nanomaterials have been an active research area due to their simplicity, ease of operation and low-cost. For these nanosensors, the analytes can in situ mediate the growth of nanomaterials in the detection system, resulting in a change of color or fluorescence of the detection system, thus allowing for the colorimetric or fluorescent detection of analytes. In the detection procedure, the detection of analytes and the formation of nanomaterials proceed simultaneously, without the requirement of labor-intensive preparation and purification operations, exhibiting promising applications. Therefore, a review on the recent progress in colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors based on the in situ formation
of nanomaterials is very necessary. In this review, we firstly compare the merits of these nanosensors utilizing in situ formed nanomaterials with that of conventional ones. Secondly, we discuss the general detection mechanism of these nanosensors. Thirdly, we highlight the remarkable achievements of these colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors in the past ten years. Lastly, we provide the current challenges and future prospects of these optical nanosensors.
2. Advantages of nanosensors based on in situ formed nanomaterials
As we all know, there two steps for the construction of conventional nanosensors, the first step involves the preparation, purification and further modification of the nanomaterials, whilst the second step is to assay the analytes under optimum conditions by utilizing the as-prepared or modified nanomaterials. The two steps require optimization of the experimental conditions and plenty of reagents, which is complicated and costly. However, for nanosensors based on in situ formed nanomaterials, the formation of the nanoparticles and the analytes assay are integrated into one step, avoiding tedious operations and environmental pollution, exhibiting their promising applications in sensing. Taking nanosensors based on AuNPs and F-CNPs as examples, the conventional nanosensor for melamine (MEL), based on MEL-induced aggregation of AuNPs, consists of two steps: the synthesis of AuNPs and the colorimetric detection of MEL using the AuNPs, which takes about 40 min to complete. A good linear relationship in the range 0.6–1.6 lM and a limit of detection (LOD) of 0.2 lM were achieved [11]. For the nanosensors utilizing MEL-caused in situ formation of AuNPs, the formation of AuNPs and the detection of MEL proceeded simultaneously, but 100 min was still required to complete the detection of MEL, and the LOD was about 0.64 nM [12]. A conventional nanosensor based on F-CNPs for sensing dopamine involves the microwave assisted preparation of the F-CNPs, purification of the F-CNPs via dialysis, modification of aminophenylboronic acid on the surface of the F-CNPs, purification of the modified F-CNPs through dialysis and detection of dopamine, which require more than 48 h [13]. However, only 30 min are demanded for the nanosensor utilizing in situ formed F-CNPs for a fluorescent assay of dopamine with the assistance of NaOH, and the LOD was 40 nM [14]. The above-mentioned examples reveal that the detection performance and time vary with nanosensors. Some nanosensors based on in situ formation of nanomaterials may require longer time to complete the detection of analytes because the detection conditions may be not suitable for the rapid formation of nanomaterials and the detection performance may be not better than that of conventional nanosensors, which may be ascribed to the fact that the signal of the in situ formed nanomaterials was not strong enough to enhance the detection performance. However, the simplicity and convenience of nanosensors on the basis of in situ formation of nanomaterials cannot be ignored and more efforts should be devoted to improve the performance of these nanosensors (Table 1).

3. Detection strategies of nanosensors based on in situ formed nanomaterials
In this review, we mainly present colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors based on in situ produced nanomaterials. In these nanosensors, the precursors of the nanomaterials and analytes are mixed together in aqueous solutions. The presence of analytes can facilitate or block the formation of various nanomaterials, yielding an obvious change in color or fluorescence. Based on the change of the optical signals, assay of analytes can be achieved. For these nanosensors, the detection of analytes and the formation of nanomaterials are combined into one simple step, without the requirement of tedious operations, exhibiting promising applications for these nanosensors. Based on the signal response modes, the detection strategies are divided into colorimetric and fluorescent strategies.

sections.heading: 3.1. Colorimetric strategy
sections.text: The present colorimetric nanosensors are mainly based on in situ formation of AuNPs and silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) [12,15–25]. Some analytes exhibited potential reducibility to in situ reduce AuCl4 or Ag+ ions into AuNPs or AgNPs, yielding obvious color changes due to the strong surface plasmon resonance effect of the AuNPs and AgNPs [15,16,18]. Ag+ ions could be also reduced by F-CNPs to in situ produce AgNPs, in which the Ag+ ion was successfully assayed [23]. In some cases, the analytes may in situ regulate the reducibility of the reducing agents by facilitating or impeding the formation of the AuNPs and AgNPs [12,17,21,25]. In addition, a change of the dispersion state of the in situ formed AgNPs moderated by analytes could also yield an obvious color change, realizing the colorimetric detection of the analytes [19,20,22,24].

sections.heading: 3.2. Fluorescent strategy
sections.text:
Currently, in situ produced CdS quantum dots (CdSQDs), fluorescent silver nanoparticles (F-AgNPs), fluorescent copper nanoparticles (F-CuNPs), F-CNPs, fluorescent silicon nanoparticles (F-SiNPs) and fluorescent cadmium nanoclusters (F-CdNCs) have been utilized to devise fluorescent nanosensors. Analytes directly or indirectly in situ moderate the formation of fluorescent nanomaterials by controlling the concentration of stabilizing agents, reducing agents or metal ions, yielding a fluorescence turn-on or turn-off response [26–33]. Some analytes may directly in situ form fluorescent nanomaterials under suitable conditions, producing a fluorescence response [14,34]. By utilizing the change of the fluorescence signal, sensitive detection of analytes has been achieved.
4. Significant advances in nanosensors based on in situ formed nanomaterials
In the section, we mainly discuss significant advances in colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors on the basis of in situ formed nanomaterials. For colorimetric detection, in situ formed AuNPs and AgNPs have been constructed into colorimetric nanosensors. Also, in situ produced CdSQDs, F-AgNPs, F-CuNPs, F-CNPs, F-SiNPs and F-CdNCs have been utilized for fluorescent sensing. Satisfactory results have been achieved in colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors by utilizing the in situ formed nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 4.1. Colorimetric detection
sections.text:
Up until now, only in situ formed AuNPs and AgNPs have been utilized to construct colorimetric nanosensors. On the one hand,
analytes could in situ reduce AuCl4 /Ag+ ions to generate AuNPs/ AgNPs. On the other hand, analytes could in situ mediate the formation of AuNPs/AgNPs by controlling the concentration and reactivity of AuCl4 /Ag+ ions or reducing agents via coordination or slow release behavior. These modes could yield obvious color changes that could be easily detected by the naked eye.

sections.heading: 4.1.1. Gold nanoparticles
sections.text:
In the past decade, AuNPs have been widely demonstrated in a variety of colorimetric nanosensors due to their extremely high extinction coefficients [4,7]. For conventional AuNPs-based colorimetric nanosensors, AuNPs are first prepared and then functionalized with some ligands, subsequently the modified AuNPs are used for the colorimetric detection of analytes based on the analytemediated dispersion of the AuNPs. These conventional colorimetric nanosensors based on AuNPs require complicated operations. However, the colorimetric nanosensors based on in situ formed AuNPs are very simple because the detection of analytes and the formation of the AuNPs are integrated into one step without the requirement for complicated operations. In these in situ formed AuNPs based nanosensors, analytes either reduce AuCl4 into AuNPs or in situ mediate the formation of AuNPs, producing obvious color changes that can easily be distinguished by the naked eye. Therefore, development of colorimetric nanosensors based in situ formed AuNPs is an active research topic.
Colorimetric detection of b-agonists was realized based on the in situ production of AuNPs caused by the reduction of HAuCl4 by the b-agonists. The reduction activity is attributed to the phenol or amine groups on the benzene ring of the b-agonists. The in situ formed AuNPs, with a strong plasmon absorption at 528 nm, exhibited a red color which could be easily observed by the naked eye, resulting in a colorimetric assay for b-agonists with linear relationships in the micro- to millimolar concentration range. Interestingly, the sensitivities differed for b-agonists with different substituent groups on the aromatic ring. The LOD of bagonists with phenol groups was lower than that of b-agonists with amine groups due to the stronger reduction activity of the phenol groups [15]. Further, the strategy was also utilized for the visual detection of tetracycline antibiotics, and the LOD could be improved to be as low as 20 ng/mL with the assistance of AuNPs seeds [16]. Furthermore, MEL was found to accelerate the formation of AuNPs via hydrogen-bonding interactions between MEL and pyrocatechol-3,5-disodiumsulfonate (PD). For PD, intramolecular hydrogen-bonding was easily formed in solution through adjacent sulfurnate and a-phenolic hydroxyl groups, causing the slow formation of AuNPs, displaying a green color. However, the addition of MEL could inhibit the formation of hydrogenbonding, releasing a -phenolic hydroxyl groups, and subsequently accelerating the formation of yellow AuNPs. On the basis of the color change from green to yellow, the concentration of MEL could be distinguished by the naked eye, and a linear relationship between the absorbance and the logarithm of the MEL concentration, ranging from 4.8 nM to 1.6 lM, and a LOD of 0.64 nM were achieved (Fig. 1A) [12].
Visual detection of lipase activity could be realized by utilizing lipase-mediated in situ growth of AuNPs. Au atoms were produced from the reduction of AuCl4 by H2O2 from the autoxidation of ethylene oxide subunits in Tween 80. At the same time, the carboxyl ester bond of Tween 80 was hydrolyzed by lipase, which controlled the rate of nucleation of the AuNPs, resulting in an obvious color change (Fig. 1B). Consequently, a linear range of 0.025–4 mg/mL and a LOD of 3.47 lg/mL for lipase detection were obtained [17].

Similarly, in situ formed AgNPs were also applied for the colorimetric detection of some analytes. There are two modes for the
colorimetric detection of analytes utilizing the in situ formation of AgNPs. The first mode is that analytes could facilitate or block the in situ formation of AgNPs by reducing Ag+ ions, inhibiting the interaction of Ag+ ions with other ligands or slowly releasing Ag+ ions. In the second mode, analytes could induce the aggregation or dispersion of the in situ formed AgNPs by interacting with the AgNPs, yielding an obvious color change. On the basis of analytemediated in situ formation of AgNPs, various analytes were successfully assayed.

Colorimetric detection of MEL was achieved based on the fact that MEL triggers the aggregation of in situ produced AgNPs from Tollens agents, producing a yellow-to-brown color change, which could easily be observed by the naked eye with a LOD of 10 nM [19]. A similar strategy was also applied for the colorimetric detection of captopril in pharmaceutical formulations [20]. Also, a colorimetric assay of Hg2+ ions was achieved via indirect enzymeinduced in situ growth of AgNPs. Horseradish peroxidase (HRP) facilitated the formation of AgNPs, whereas an excess of H2O2 inhibited the formation of AgNPs. Subsequently, the presence of the enzyme substrate 2,20-azino-bis(3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sul fonic acid) diammonium salt (ABTS) could recover HRP activity for the in situ generation of AgNPs because ABTS is converted into the radical cation (ABTS +) by H2O2. The addition of Hg2+ ions impedes the HRP activity, causing the aggregation of AgNPs. The nanosensor allowed the colorimetric analysis of Hg2+ ions with a LOD of 0.78 nM. Moreover, the proposed probe was applied for sensing Hg2+ ions in real water samples with good results [22].
Recently, F-CNPs prepared from pectin acted as the reductant and stabilizer for the in situ growth of yellow AgNPs, producing a colorimetric probe for an Ag+ ions assay with a LOD of 7 lM [23]. Further, MEL was also found to cause the aggregation of the in situ formed AgNPs in the presence of F-CNPs, yielding an obvious color change from yellow to red. Thus, a colorimetric method for a MEL assay was developed with an excellent LOD of 7.9 10 12 g/ mL. The practical applications of the proposed method were successfully used to detect MEL in cow’s milk and milk powder [24]. Shen et al. found thiols, including cysteine (Cys), homocysteine (Hcy) and GSH, facilitated the growth of AgNPs because the Ag+biothiol complex gradually released free Ag+ ions that could be reduced by the F-CNPs. If there are no thiols, free Ag+ ions bound on the surface of excessive F-CNPs, subsequently blocking the growth of AgNPs. Thus, the colorimetric assay of thiols was accomplished with 1.5 nM, 2.6 nM and 1.2 nM for Cys, Hcy and GSH, respectively (Fig. 2B) [25]. However, Cys, Hcy and GSH could be not distinguished by this approach.
These colorimetric nanosensors based on in situ generated nanomaterials were successfully devised to sense a variety of analytes. However, the performance of some colorimetric nanosensors is not as good as expected, and the interference from strong reducing agents or coordination agents may be not avoided; the real applications are too simple. Therefore, great efforts should be devoted to developing sensitive, rapid and robust nanosensors. These colorimetric nanosensors are listed in Table 2 to compare their performance.

sections.heading: 4.2. Fluorescent detection
sections.text: Besides the aforementioned colorimetric methods, in situ produced CdSQDs, F-AgNPs, F-CuNPs, F-CNPs, F-SiNPs and F-CdNCs have been utilized for the fluorescent sensing of various analytes without the requirement of tedious operations.

sections.heading: 4.2.1. CdS quantum dots
sections.text:
CdSQDs with bright fluorescence exhibit the potential for applications in sensing, cell imaging and other fields [35,36]. Pavlov’s group developed a series of novel nanosensors based on enzymemediated in situ generation of CdSQDs [26–28]. In these assays, various enzymes are utilized to hydrolyze different substrates to release small molecules, which could facilitate or block the formation of CdSQDs, resulting in fluorescence turn on or turn off. The change of the fluorescence signal is related to the concentration of the analytes, producing fluorescent nanosensors. Serum paraoxonase (PON1) was assayed via a fluorescence turn-off mechanism based on the in situ formation of CdSQDs. PON1 hydrolyzed Sphenyl thioacetate to release thiophenol, that inhibited the growth of CdSQDs in the presence of Cd2+ ions, S2 ions and sodium thiophosphate, resulting in low fluorescence. The approach allowed the detection of PON1 with a dynamic range up to 5 U/L and a lowest activity of 0.625 U/L. The feasibility of the method was further evaluated in human serum (Fig. 3A) [37]. The proposed strategy is general and was also utilized for the determination of amifostine, alkaline phosphatase [38] and a-fetoprotein (AFP) [39].
The small molecules released by the hydrolysis of an enzyme can also facilitate the growth of CdSQDs or stabilize CdSQDs, producing fluorescence turn-on nanosensors. For example, Pavlov’s group found that the substrate S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine could be hydrolyzed to Hcy by S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine hydrolase (AHCY), and the yielded Hcy could subsequently be decomposed into H2S by methionine c-lyase (MGL). The produced H2S reacts with Cd2+ ions to form CdSQDs with bright fluorescence. By taking the advantage of these enzymatic reactions, fluorescence turn-on
assays for MGL and AHCY were achieved with excellent sensitivity. Meanwhile, the proposed approach was also applied to screen AHCY inhibitors (Fig. 3B) [40]. On the basis of the same approach, glucose oxidase, horseradish peroxidase and glucose were successfully assayed [41].
Moreover, Pavlov’s group also noticed inorganic phosphate could stabilize in situ formed CdSQDs by the interaction of Cd2+ ions with S2 ions. The inorganic phosphate could be released from the hydrolysis of p-nitrophenyl phosphate, catalyzed by alkaline phosphatase (ALP), a larger amount of ALP could yield more inorganic phosphate, producing stronger fluorescence. Thus, some target antibodies could be detected via an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and the ALP-labelled antibody. Accordingly, as low as 0.4 ng/mL of the target antibody was determined, which is one order of magnitude lower than that of the colorimetric method utilizing a p-nitrophenyl phosphate assay (Fig. 3C) [42]. This strategy was also applied to assay for the cancer biomarker superoxide dismutase 2 (SOD2) with a LOD of 0.44 ng/ mL, exhibiting two orders of magnitude better than that of other reported results [43]. It was then observed that Cys could stabilize the in situ generation of CdSQDs, producing bright fluorescence. However, Cys is aerobically oxidized to cystine by the peroxidase mimicking DNAzyme (peroxidase-DNAzyme), decreasing the fluorescence because cystine does not stabilize the in situ produced CdSQDs. The catalytic activity of peroxidase-DNAzyme modified with the recognition hairpin sequence could be adjusted by the analytes because the presence of the analytes could destroy the peroxidase-DNAzyme structure, subsequently enhancing the fluorescence. Taking DNA and ATP as a model, they were successfully assayed, but the sensitivity should be further improved [44]. In addition, thiocholine from the hydrolysis of acetylcholine catalyzed by acetylcholinesterase (AChE) was found to stabilize the in situ formed CdSQDs with strong fluorescence, producing a fluorescence turn-on nanosensor for sensing AChE activity, with the linear range of 1–10 mU/mL. The inhibitors of AChE were also detected via a fluorescence turn-off response [45]. These nanosensors based on the in situ growth CdSQDs displayed excellent performance, providing reliable strategies for the design of fluorescent
nanosensors. However, the introduction of toxic Cd2+ ions is one of the drawbacks; similar approaches utilizing low toxic or nontoxic reagents should be further explored.

sections.heading: 4.2.2. Fluorescent silver nanoparticles
sections.text:
F-AgNPs, emerging fluorescent metal nanoparticles, have attracted significant attention due to their unique properties and potential applications in a wide range of fields [46–48]. The past reported results revealed that peptides, polymers, a cytosine-rich sequence or similar single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) could be templates for the generation of F-AgNPs, using NaBH4 as the reducing agent; Ag+ ions are entrapped in these templates via coordination [46]. The addition of analytes could in situ regulate the formation F-AgNPs, changing the fluorescence intensity of the F-AgNPs, as a result, the detection of analytes could be realized.
Lin’s group developed a fluorescence turn-on approach for sensing glucose by utilizing the in situ formation of F-AgNPs with the assistance of UV illumination. In the proposed method, glucose was oxidized by glucose oxidase, yielding H2O2. The Fenton reaction between the produced H2O2 and Fe2+ ions could produce reactive radicals, inducing the polymerization of methacrylic acid to generate poly(methacrylic acid), which served as the template for the formation of F-AgNPs under UV light. The fluorescence intensity of the F-AgNPs increased with the concentration of glucose. Accordingly, the content of glucose was quantified. Nonetheless, the reactive radicals are unstable and so are easily quenched in a complicated system (Fig. 4A) [29].
DNA is usually utilized as the template for the in situ generation of F-AgNPs. A single-stranded sequence containing a 15-nt poly (thymine) (poly T) spacer between two different emitters was designed by Ye’s group to detect pyrophosphate (PPi) and ALP. They found that the combination of Cu2+ ions and DNA template inhibited the generation of DNA/F-AgNPs, resulting in low fluorescence. However, the addition of PPi could significantly enhance the fluorescence of the post-formed F-AgNPs because of the strong coordination interaction between Cu2+ ions and PPi. As a result, sensitive detection of PPi was accomplished with a linear relationship ranging from 0.25 lM to 10 lM and a LOD of 112.69 nM. The
above sensing system also detected ALP because ALP could catalyze PPi to transform into orthophosphate with a weak binding capacity for Cu2+ ions, producing low fluorescence. By virtue of the mechanism, ALP was determined in a linear range of 0.03–0.24 U/mL and the LOD for detection of ALP was about 0.005 U/mL (Fig. 4B) [30]. He’s group found that ascorbic acid could reduce Ag+ ions into AgNPs, blocking the in situ formation of F-AgNPs. Ascorbic acid is released from the hydrolysis of ascorbic acid 2-phosphate catalyzed by ALP. Based on the ALP-mediated in situ formation of F-AgNPs, the ALP activity was identified with a good linearity ranging from 1 U/L to 100 U/L. The LOD was found to be 0.63 U/L [49]. Similarly, this strategy was applied for an immunoassay of AFP based on Cu2+-regulated in situ generation of DNA-template F-Cu/AgNPs. As a result, a linear relationship between the change of fluorescence intensity and the concentration of AFP in the range 10–150 ng/mL was achieved. The LOD was about 4 ng/mL. A practical application of the assay was demonstrated in human serum (Fig. 4C) [50]. Moreover, Cui et al. observed the gap site in DNA duplexes could act as a new scaffold to facilitate the rapid formation of F-AgNPs, which could be utilized for the detection of single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP). In the detection system, two short oligo single-stranded DNA (oligo-ssDNA) strands were designed to capture the target long oligo-ssDNA to form a duplex, yielding a gap site at the formed DNA duplex. When cytosine faced toward the gap site in the DNA duplex, F-AgNPs with a strong red emission easily formed at the gap site of the DNA duplex due to the specific interaction between cytosine and Ag+ ions. As a result, the wild type from mutated forms related to the codon 177 of p53 gene was distinguished (Fig. 4D) [51]. The in situ formation of F-AgNPs was successfully applied to sense various analytes, however, expensive DNA was demanded, which required us to operate with cautiousness.

sections.heading: 4.2.3. Fluorescent copper nanoparticles
sections.text:
Compared with F-AgNPs, F-CuNPs exhibit low-cost and ease of fabrication. The passed decades have witnessed great progress in their preparation and applications [5]. The in situ formation of FCuNPs has been employed to construct lots of fluorescent nanosensors for metal ions, small molecules and biomolecules [3,5]. In these nanosensors based on in situ formed F-CuNPs, doublestranded DNA (dsDNA) or poly T served as the template for the in situ formation of F-CuNPs. Cu2+ ions firstly coordinate with T to generate dsDNA-Cu2+ or poly T-Cu2+ complexes, the addition of sodium ascorbate could then induce the formation of F-CuNPs. In the formation procedure of F-CuNPs, the presence of analytes moderates the fluorescence signal by controlling the concentration of Cu2+/ascorbate or the structure of dsDNA or poly T caused via coordination or enzymes [5]. To date, a series of nanosensors have been developed by utilizing the in situ formation of DNA-stabilized F-CuNPs.
Qing et al. described a rapid assay for Cu2+ ions using poly T as the template to stabilize the F-CuNPs in the presence of sodium ascorbate. The fluorescence intensity of the F-CuNPs was proportional to the Cu2+ ion concentration. As a result, sensitive detection of Cu2+ ions with a linear relationship ranging from 10 to 35 lM and a LOD of 5.6 lMwas accomplished. The approach was successfully applied in Cu2+-polluted tap water and river water. Moreover, the method was used to screen the toxicity of Cu2+ ions (Fig. 5A) [31]. Based on the strong coordination between Cu2+ ions and Lhistidine, Wang’s group designed a fluorescence turn-off nanosensor for the selective detection of L-histidine utilizing ds-DNA stabilized F-CuNPs as fluorescent probes. In the presence of L-histidine, the specific interaction between Cu2+ ions and L-histidine could block the formation of F-CuNPs, resulting in a decrease of the fluorescence intensity. As a result, the concentration of L-histidine
could be detected by the fluorescent changes. The fluorescence intensity was observed to be linearly related to the concentration of L-histidine in the range 0.2–100 lM, and the LOD was estimated to be about 20 nM. Other amino acids, except for Cys, exhibit no interference with the detection of L-histidine. The interference of Cys could be eliminated by N-ethylmaleimide (NEM) because NEM can react with the thiol groups of Cys. The proposed nanosensor was applied for sensing L-histidine in human urine (Fig. 5B) [32]. Utilizing the same strategy, kojic acid was also detected using F-CuNPs, with a linear range of 0.1–300 lM and a LOD of 30 nM [52].
Song et al. designed an aptasensor for fluorescence turn-on detection of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) based on the in situ formation of F-CuNPs and the specific digestion capability of exonuclease I (Exo I). The ssDNA contained the aptamer for ATP and

The remaining poly T at the 50-terminus of the substrate DNA acted as the template for the formation of F-CuNPs with a red emission in buffered solution. Based on this observation, fluorescence turn-on detection of ATP was accomplished with the linear range 0.2–50 lM and a LOD of 93 nM. The probe was successfully applied in RPMI 1640 cell medium (Fig. 6A) [53].
A highly sensitive and selective probe for sensing DNA was proposed by Zhang’s group. In the strategy, the 30 end of capture DNA was immobilized on the surface of streptavidin-functionalized magnetic beads (SA-MB), which could capture the target DNA

Surface initiated enzymatic polymerization (SIEP) was utilized as the signal amplification method to yield poly T at the 30 end of tDNA for the generation of F-CuNPs, resulting in about a 35.7 fold signal amplification by comparison with the dsDNA after hybridization without SIEP. Accordingly, tDNA was successfully detected with the linear range 0.1–10 nM and a LOD of 98.2 pM [54]. The strategy was sensitive to the mismatch type of the specific DNA sequence, which could discriminate single nucleotide mismatches. The method did not require any strict temperature control, complicated equipment or special operations.
The sensitive detection of microRNA (miRNA) could be also realized by virtue of a target recycling amplification-integrated superlong poly T-hosted F-CuNPs approach. In the assay, duplexspecific nuclease (DSN) served as a convertor, which could cut complementary dsDNA or DNA in the DNA/RNA heteroduplex, and showed no activity on ssDNA or RNA. Thus, a 30- phosphorylated DNA was designed to capture the target RNA and then was cleaved by DSN to yield the 30-hydroxylated fragments, which acted as primers of TdT to form the superlong poly T tails for F-CuNPs generation. Taking let-7d miRNA as an example, a good linear range from 20 pM to 1000 pM and a LOD of 20 pMwere obtained [55]. The strategy could identify homologous and heterologous miRNAs, revealing the promising applications in gene and disease testing.
Enzyme activity could be also assayed via the in situ formation of F-CuNPs. Wang’s group proposed a facile method for detecting S1 nuclease by utilizing the S1 nuclease-mediated formation of FCuNPs. In the absence of S1 nuclease, the signal reporter of poly T of 30 mer (T30) remained the original long state, which served as the template for the production of F-CuNPs with strong fluorescence. However, the addition of S1 nuclease could digest poly T to mono- or oligonucleotide fragments, blocking the formation of FCuNPs, as a result, low or no fluorescence was observed. Taking the advantage of the fluorescence turn-off response mode, rapid detection of S1 nuclease was accomplishedwith a linear range from 5 10 6 to 2 10 3 units/lL and a LODof 5 10 7 units/lL.Moreover, this approach was further used to screen nuclease inhibitors (Fig. 6B) [56]. Based on a similar strategy, acetylcholinesterase (Fig. 6C) [57] and terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase [58] were successfully determined with excellent sensitivity.
Moreover, a fluorescent ELISA, utilizing enzyme-mediated formation of F-CuNPs, was designed by Yang’s group. In the strategy, the antigen was adsorbed onto 96-well microplates via a nonspecific physical adsorption. Then the primary antibody was introduced to specially capture the antigen, sequentially, the ALPlabelled second antibody was added to bind the primary antibody. The labelled ALP could hydrolyze ascorbic acid 2-phosphate into ascorbic acid, and the produced ascorbic acid could induce the formation of F-CuNPs. More antigens could increase the concentration of the captured ALP, leading to a stronger fluorescence of the FCuNPs. Taking human IgG as a model, a quasi-linear relationship in the range 5–200 ng/mL and a LOD of 5 ng/mL were obtained (Fig. 6D) [59]. From the above-mentioned examples, we can see that the in situ formation of F-CuNPs has been widely utilized to detect various analytes. However, deliberately designed DNA was required and interferences that affect the concentration and state of the Cu2+ ion, sodium ascorbate and DNA may influence the in situ formation of F-CuNPs, producing inaccurate results. Thus, continuous efforts should be devoted to improving their performance and designing robust fluorescent nanosensors.

sections.heading: 4.2.4. Fluorescent carbon nanoparticles
sections.text:
F-CNPs have received considerable attention due to their excellent biocompatibility, low toxicity, high photostability, low-cost and ease of fabrication, exhibiting promising applications in a vari-
ety of fields, including photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, biomedicine, optoelectronics, cell imaging, sensors and so on [60–62]. It should be noted that F-CNPs involve various fluorescent carbonbased nanoparticles, including carbon quantum dots, fluorescent polydopamine nanoparticles (FPDA), polylevodopa nanoparticles and fluorescent polymethyldopa nanoparticles (F-PMNPs). The procedures for conventional F-CNPs-based nanosensors include preparation, purification of F-CNPs and detection of analytes using F-CNPs, requiring tedious operations. To overcome these drawbacks, some fluorescent probes were devised via the in situ formation of F-CNPs because the formation of F-CNPs and detection of analytes simultaneously proceed without complicated operations. For most of these fluorescent nanoprobes, the analytes were directly transformed into F-CNPs under suitable conditions. Additionally, some analytes could assist or mediate the in situ formation of F-CNPs. Based on the change of the fluorescence signal, analytes were sensitively assayed.
Costas-Mora and co-workers presented a fluorescent method for sensing methylmercury by employing the in situ ultrasoundassisted synthesis of F-CNPs as optical nanoprobes. For the formation of the F-CNPs, fructose was used as the carbon source, poly (ethylene glycol) (PEG) acted as a passivation agent, ethanol could increase the reaction kinetics and NaOH was employed to enhance the fluorescence intensity of the F-CNPs. In the detection procedure, low amounts of these precursors and samples containing methylmercury were mixed and underwent ultrasound treatment for 1 min. Micro-volume fluorospectrometry was utilized for the measurement of the fluorescence quenching caused by methylmercury. Due to the hydrophobicity of methylmercury and its ability to facilitate a non-radiative electron/hole recombination, the fluorescence of the in situ formed F-CNPs was quenched. As a result, a LOD of 5.9 nM methylmercury and good repeatability were obtained. Also, the method was successfully applied in the analysis of water samples and marine animal tissues (Fig. 7A) [63].
Kim’s group found that FPDA could easily be formed in the presence of hydrogen peroxide and Cu2+ ions under a nitrogen atmosphere and the fluorescence intensity of FPDA was strongly dependent on the concentration of the Cu2+ ions. Consequently, the fluorescence turn-on detection of Cu2+ ions was successfully realized with a LOD as low as 1 nM [64]. Yildirim and Bayindir developed a fluorescence turn-on assay for dopamine based on the in situ formation FPDA from the polymerization reaction of dopamine initiated by NaOH. The addition of HCl could terminate the polymerization reaction, keeping the fluorescence intensity constant. As a result, sensitive and selective detection of dopamine were accomplished with a LOD of 40 nM. Due to the simplicity and low cost, the proposed method is promising for the detection of dopamine related diseases (Fig. 7B) [14]. Recently, Zheng’s group constructed another fluorescence turn-on strategy for the rapid detection of dopamine using ficin as a peroxidase-mimic to in situ form FPDA. Ficin, possessing an intrinsic peroxidase-like activity, could catalyze the oxidization of dopamine to its quinone derivative, which autopolymerized into fluorescent FPDA in the presence of H2O2, resulting in the gradual increase of the fluorescence intensity with the increasing concentration of dopamine. As a consequence, sensitive detection of dopamine with a good linear relationship in the range of 10 nM–5.0 lM and a LOD of 5.5 nM were achieved. The method was further utilized to detect dopamine in human serum samples [65]. A fluorescence turn-on method for the rapid detection of levodopa (4- dihydroxyphenylalanine, L-DOPA) was developed based on the in situ formation of polylevodopa nanoparticles due to the fact that L-DOPA is easily oxidized to its quinturnone derivative under alkaline conditions. The proposed method exhibited good selectivity towards L-DOPA, even in the presence of dopamine, uric acid and
other interferents. A detection performance with a linear range of 0.3–100.0 lM and a LOD of 29.0 nM was acquired. Also, the reported approach was successfully applied to assay L-DOPA in plasma samples [66].
Yang’s group recently proposed a fluorescence turn-on strategy for sensing tyrosinase activity by utilizing tyrosinase-induced in situ formation of F-PMNPs. In this context, tyrosinase catalytically transformed metyrosine into methyldopa, then the produced methyldopa reacted with ethanolamine to yield F-PMNPs with maximum fluorescence emission at 525 nm. The fluorescence intensity was directly proportional to the concentration of tyrosinase, resulting in the sensitive and selective detection of tyrosinase activity with a linear range of 0.40–7.0 U/mL and a LOD of 0.10 U/ mL. Furthermore, the designed method was also applied to screen tyrosinase inhibitor, showing potential applications of the proposed method [67]. Also, a fluorescence turn-on nanosensor for ampicillin was developed by employing the in situ formation of F-CNPs through a hydrothermal reaction between glucose and ampicillin. The formed F-CNPs showed a maximum emission wavelength at 437 nm when excited at 340 nm. The fluorescence intensity at 437 nm gradually increased on increasing of the concentration of ampicillin. As a result, the system for the detection of ampicillin exhibited a LOD of 16.5 lM and a linear range of 6.6–200 ppm [68]. However, the method required a high tempera-
ture and a long reaction time, and the selectivity was not evaluated.
Lin et al. developed an approach for a fluorescent immunoassay for AFP by combining the enzyme-controlled formation of FPDA and the dissolution of MnO2 nanoflakes caused by AA. Initially, a conventional sandwich-type immunoreaction was constructed using antibody/ascorbate oxidase-conjugating gold nanoparticles as the detection probe. The carried ascorbate oxidase captured by the AFP could oxidize ascorbic acid into dehydroascorbic acid, thus the dissolution of MnO2 nanoflakes was inhibited, resulting in the production of FPDA because the MnO2 nanoflakes could oxidize dopamine into the quinone derivative. Therefore, the fluorescence intensity of FPDA increased with the increasing AFP concentration with a linear range of 0.05–20 ng/mL and a LOD of 17.3 pg/mL. Also, the proposed sensor exhibited high specificity and acceptable accuracy for sensing AFP. This methodology provides a facile approach for the detection of other targets (Fig. 7C) [69]. The above-mentioned examples revealed that analytes with suitable molecular structures, such as phenolic hydroxyl groups, could be transformed into F-CNPs, but interferents that exhibit similar properties may affect the detection of the analytes. Thus, robust and selective fluorescent nanosensors based on in situ formed F-CNPs are highly desirable, and their practical applications need further research.

sections.heading: 4.2.5. Fluorescent silicon nanoparticles
sections.text:
Fluorescent silicon nanoparticles F-SiNPs, which are newly emerging fluorescent nanomaterials, have recently attracted considerable interest because of their unique properties and promising applications in various fields [70,71]. Wang et al. have observed
that sodium ascorbate reacts with aminosilane to generate F-SiNPs at room temperature, and ascorbate with higher concentrations yields brighter fluorescence [72]. Thus, the formation of F-SiNPs could be in situ mediated by analytes by controlling the concentration of ascorbate, providing an avenue for constructing
fluorescent nanosensors. Yang’s group proposed a fluorescent approach for ALP activity sensing and inhibitor screening based on the ALP-catalyzed transformation of ascorbic acid 2- phosphate into AA, and the produced AA could interact with aminosilane (no fluorescence) to yield F-SiNPs with a cyan fluorescent emission. They further constructed a fluorescence immunoassay system utilizing the original ALP-enabled in situ formation of FSiNPs on the basis of the conventional ALP-based ELISA platform. Taking AFP as the model antigen target, the proposed method could evaluate 1 ng/mL of analyte using fluorescence spectroscopy and 5 ng/mL with a naked eye readout under an ultraviolet lamp, indicating promising applications for this methodology in clinical medicine examination and disease diagnosis (Fig. 8A) [33]. Results on nanosensors utilizing the in situ formation of F-SiNPs are still rare, thus, much attention should be paid to develop novel fluorescent nanosensors.

sections.heading: 4.2.6. Fluorescent cadmium nanoclusters
sections.text:
F-CdNCs are rarely prepared due to their toxicity. However, the in situ formation of F-CdNCs could be utilized for the fluorescent detection of Cd2+ ions. Recently, Noh and his coworkers proposed a fluorescence turn-on method for sensing Cd2+ ions based on the in situ formation of F-CdNCs in human serum albumin (HSA) with the assistance of NaOH. The production of F-CdNCs was attributed to the reduction of the entrapped Cd2+ ions by some functional groups in HSA under alkaline conditions. The fluorescence intensity increased with the concentration of Cd2+ ions, resulting in the ultrasensitive detection of Cd2+ ions with a LOD of 15.68 fM. Furthermore, practical applications of the developed method were evaluated for tap, fountain and pond water samples with satisfactory results (Fig. 8B) [34]. The above results provide a general approach for sensing other analytes, so further research should be carried out.
The above mentioned in situ formed nanomaterials were successfully applied for the fluorescent sensing of various analytes. To compare their performance, we have summarized these results in Table 3.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion and future perspectives
sections.text:
In conclusion, we have highlighted the remarkable advances in colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors by utilizing the in situ formation of nanomaterials. In these nanosensors, detection of analytes and formation of nanomaterials are combined into one step without tedious operations, displaying promising applications for the future. However, many challenges are still present. Firstly, the present colorimetric nanosensors mainly focus on in situ formed AuNPs and AgNPs. New colorimetric nanosensors utilizing in situ formed nanomaterials with low cost and low toxicity should be further developed. Similarly, in situ formed fluorescent nanomaterials with low toxicity are also needed to constructed novel nanosensors. Secondly, most of the detection mechanisms of the present nanosensors are signal off, which are easily affected by the detection environment, yielding inaccurate results. Novel detection strategies are highly desirable, such as a ratiometric response that can reduce the influence of the detection media and improve the accuracy of detection results. Thirdly, most of the present nanosensors are preliminarily applied in real samples. The applications in complex samples should be further investigated. Further development of point-of-care platforms based on the in situ formation of nanomaterials is extremely urgent. Meanwhile, robust nanosensors should be further developed, so they can be utilized in complex real samples with satisfactory results, simplifying the present detection techniques. Fourthly, the sensitivity and selectivity of some nanosensors are not excellent, the
performance of some nanosensors is even inferior to that of conventional nanosensors. Thus, effective strategies should be developed to improve their sensitivity, selectivity and response time. Last, but not least, these nanosensors are only utilized to detect analytes, so the harm of some toxic analytes is not eliminated. Nanosensors with dual functions of detection and removal of toxic analytes are urgently demanded. With the rapid development of nanotechnology, more novel nanosensors from the in situ generation of nanomaterials with excellent performance will spring up.

metadata.abstractText: The past decades have witnessed significant advances in nanoscience and technology, especially in the variety of colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors. Among these nanosensors, colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors based on in situ formed nanomaterials have attracted much attention due to their ease of operation and high sensitivity. This review focuses on the significant achievements of the past ten years in colorimetric and fluorescent nanosensors by utilizing in situ produced nanomaterials, including gold nanoparticles, silver nanoparticles, CdS quantum dots, fluorescent silver nanoparticles, fluorescent copper nanoparticles, carbon quantum dots, fluorescent silicon nanoparticles and fluorescent cadmium nanoclusters. At the end of the review, the challenges and future directions are presented. 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
